Title: Randomised Controlled Trial on Diesel Particulate Matter-Induced Ischemic Heart Disease

Background: Ischemic heart disease (IHD) is a major cardiovascular health concern, with diesel particulate matter (DPM) as a significant environmental risk factor. This study aimed to identify biomarkers and mechanisms of DPM-induced myocardial hypoxia injury.

Methods: A cohort of diesel engine testers (DETs) with stable DPM exposure was studied. Participants underwent electrocardiogram and echocardiogram examinations, serum myocardial enzyme assessments, and a 6-min walking test. A mouse model exposed to occupational DPM doses and in vitro models were used to assess mitochondrial aerobic metabolism. Ion fluorescence probes, ion supplements, and mitochondrial RNA splicing protein 2 (Mrs2) overexpression transfection were employed to investigate mitochondrial Mg²⁺ deficiency mechanisms.

Results: Compromised myocardial mitochondrial aerobic metabolism was identified as a precursor biomarker for myocardial hypertrophy and hypoxia injury in DPM exposure. DPM induced mitochondrial Mg²⁺ deficiency, disrupting aerobic metabolism processes, including the tricarboxylic acid cycle, oxidative phosphorylation, and ATP synthesis. Mg²⁺ deficiency was mediated by the disruption of Mg²⁺ transport proteins, such as DPM-enhanced hyperubiquitination and degradation of Mrs2. The study found that Mg²⁺ supplementation alleviated DPM-mediated disruptions, suggesting a potential intervention strategy.

Interpretation: Compromised mitochondrial aerobic metabolism, associated with Mg²⁺ deficiency, serves as a critical biomarker for DPM-induced IHD and represents a promising avenue for intervention. The findings highlight the importance of addressing environmental risk factors in cardiovascular health and suggest that Mg²⁺ supplementation could mitigate DPM-induced cardiovascular risks.

Trial registration: Not provided.

Funding: Not specified.
